questions.text: A 15-year-old tall boy with long limbs presents to the OPD. On ocular examination, bilateral ectopia lentis is noted. Which gene is most likely affected in this inherited disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. FBN1 (Fibrillin-1)

  • Bilateral ectopia lentis in a tall individual with long limbs is classic for Marfan syndrome, which is caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene on chromosome 15.
  • Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder.
  • Pathophysiology: Defective fibrillin leads to abnormal connective tissue elasticity and excess TGF-β activation.

Clinical features

  • Ocular features: Ectopia lentis (usually superotemporal lens subluxation), myopia, risk of retinal detachment.
  • Skeletal features: Tall stature, arachnodactyly, long limbs (dolichostenomelia), pectus deformities, scoliosis.
  • Cardiovascular: Aortic root dilation, aneurysm, aortic regurgitation, mitral valve prolapse—major cause of mortality.

Management: Regular cardiovascular monitoring, beta-blockers or ARBs to slow aortic dilation, surgical repair when needed.

COL5A (Option A) mutations cause Ehlers–Danlos syndrome (classic type), presenting with hyperextensible skin, hypermobile joints, and poor wound healing, not isolated ectopia lentis.

PAX6 (Option B) is associated with aniridia and other anterior segment dysgenesis disorders, not Marfan syndrome.

TGFβR2 (Option C) mutations cause Loeys–Dietz syndrome, which shares aortic aneurysms with Marfan’s but usually has hypertelorism, bifid uvula, and no typical lens dislocation.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with white, dandruff-like deposits on the anterior lens surface, seen during slit-lamp examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Pseudoexfoliation syndrome

  • Based on the above findings,the patient has pseudoexfoliation syndrome, characterized by the deposition of whitish-gray, dandruff-like fibrillar material on the anterior lens capsule and pupillary margin. This appearance is also called the hoarfrost sign. The material is best seen after pupil dilation and often appears in a concentric ring pattern. It is strongly associated with secondary open-angle glaucoma due to blockage of the trabecular meshwork by exfoliated material and pigment.
  • Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is an age-related systemic condition with ocular manifestations involving abnormal production and accumulation of extracellular fibrillar material in ocular tissues. This is due to abnormal basement membrane metabolism → deposition of pseudoexfoliative material in anterior segment structures (lens capsule, iris, zonules, ciliary body).

Management: Regular IOP monitoring, antiglaucoma medications as needed, careful cataract surgery planning.

Iris cyst (Option B): Localized iris mass; does not cause diffuse frosted deposits on the lens capsule.

Persistent pupillary membrane (Option C): Remnant of tunica vasculosa lentis; appears as thin strands across the pupil, not concentric whitish deposits.

Pigment dispersion syndrome (Option D): Pigment granules deposited on corneal endothelium (Krukenberg’s spindle) and trabecular meshwork; lacks the characteristic fibrillar white deposits of pseudoexfoliation.

questions.text: After the uneventful placement of an intraocular lens in a young patient during cataract surgery, what further steps should be taken?

choices.text:
Relaced when secondary cataract develops

Replaced when presbyopia develops

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B

  • Never replaced: In most cases, the IOL does not need to be replaced unless there are complications or issues with the lens. Modern IOLs are designed to be permanent and durable, and they can last a lifetime without causing any problems.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. IOL replaced every 10 years: There is no fixed time interval for replacing the IOL unless there are complications or specific indications for its replacement. Routine replacement every 10 years is not necessary.

Option C. Replaced when secondary cataract develops: Secondary cataract, also known as posterior capsule opacification, can occur after cataract surgery. It is a common complication where the posterior capsule, which holds the IOL in place, becomes cloudy. In such cases, a laser procedure called YAG capsulotomy can be performed to clear the visual axis and restore clear vision, without replacing the IOL itself.

Option D. Replaced when presbyopia develops: Presbyopia is a natural age-related condition that affects near vision. It occurs due to the loss of flexibility in the natural lens of the eye, not the IOL. If presbyopia develops after cataract surgery, other options such as glasses, contact lenses, or additional surgical procedures like monovision correction may be considered, but replacing the IOL is not typically necessary.

questions.text: What is the average degree of hypermetropia in a newborn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - +2.5 D

Explanation:

  • Newborns are physiologically hypermetropic, with an average refractive error of approximately +2.5 to 3 diopters.
  • This occurs because the axial length of the eye is shorter at birth, and the eye grows over time, reducing hypermetropia.
  • Hypermetropia, or long-sightedness, is a refractive error in which parallel rays of light from distant objects focus behind the retina when the eye's accommodation is relaxed.

Type of Hypermetropia

Cause

Axial Hypermetropia

Shortening of the eyeball's axial length. Commonest form.

Curvatural Hypermetropia

Flatter curvature of the cornea, lens, or both.

Index Hypermetropia

Decreased refractive index of the lens, usually due to cortical sclerosis in old age or in treated diabetics.

Positional Hypermetropia

Posterior displacement of the crystalline lens.

Aphakia

Absence of the crystalline lens, either congenital or acquired (e.g., after surgery), leads to high hypermetropia.

Consecutive Hypermetropia

Overcorrected myopia after refractive surgery (e.g., LASIK, ICL) or underpowered intraocular lens (IOL) after cataract surgery.

Features:

  • Small eyeball in high hypermetropia
  • Smaller cornea
  • Shallow anterior chamber
  • Fundus Examination:
    • Optic disc - Small , ill-defined margins, possibly simulating papillitis (pseudopapillitis).
    • Retina - Shot silk appearance (shining retina).

+1 D (Option D): +1 D is below the average hypermetropia seen in newborns. This degree of refractive error is more commonly observed in older children or adults after emmetropization has occurred.

questions.text: What could be the most probable cause for the progressive vision loss in both eyes of a 25-year-old male who has been undergoing low-dose oral steroid therapy for the past decade?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cataract

Explanation:

  • The most likely reason for the progressive loss of vision in a 25-year-old male who has been on low-dose oral steroid therapy for the last 10 years is Cataract.

Toxic cataract:

  • Steroids - Prolonged use in high doses may cause posterior subcapsular cataracts. Children are more susceptible

  • Other causes of posterior subcapsular cataract: Galactosemia, Myotonic dystrophy, BLUNT trauma, complicated cataract, chloroquine, busulfan, NF2,

  • Glaucoma by TOPICAL steroids (Option B) and cataract by SYSTEMIC STEROIDS (mnemonic: GTCS)

  • Miotics - Especially long-acting cholinesterase inhibitors such as echothiophate, demecarium bromide, and diisopropyl fluorophosphate (DFP) may cause anterior subcapsular-granular cataracts

  • Other causes of anterior subcapsular cataract - Amiodarone, chlorpromazine, busulfan, gold, and allopurinol

  • AACG ( Mnemonic): Atopic dermatitis- shield cataract, Amiodarone, Chlorpromazine, Gold deposit, AACG(acute angle closure glaucoma)

Incorrect Options

Glaucoma (Option B) is the most common complication of topical steroids.

Cystoid macular edema (Option C) may be associated with steroid use, but it typically presents with symptoms such as blurry vision, central vision loss, and distortion.

Retinal detachment (Option D) causes progressive loss of vision which is not consistent with the above described case.

questions.text:
True statement regarding KF ring:


	Seen in all patient with neurological involvement
	Is pathognomonic for Wilson’s disease
	Resolves with desferroxamine
	Seen in all patients with hepatic involvement
	Seen in superior and inferior descemets membrane
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1 and 5

Explanation:

Statement 1: KF ring is seen on all patients with neurologic symptoms because neurological symptoms are caused due to deposition of copper in basal ganglia, thus can deposit in cornea

Statement 2: KF ring are seen in Wilson disease, primary biliary cholangitis and neonatal cholestasis

Statement 4: KF ring is seen in only 50% patients with hepatic involvement

 

Wilson disease:

Hepatolenticular degeneration

Pathophysiology:

  • Autosomal recessive (positive family history)
  • Mutation in ATP7B gene (copper transporting P-type adenosine triphosphatase (ATPase), present in chromosome 13 (13q14).
  • Decreased biliary copper excretion and diffuse accumulation of copper in the cytosol of hepatocytes.
  • Later, copper is redistributed to other tissues once the liver is saturated with copper.

Clinical features:

  • Liver: Asymptomatic hepatomegaly (with or without splenomegaly), subacute or chronic hepatitis, acute hepatic failure, and portal hypertension
  • Neurology: Intention tremor, dysarthria, rigid dystonia, Parkinsonism, choreiform movements, lack of motor coordination, deterioration in school performance, psychosis, or behavioral changes
  • Psychiatric manifestations: Depression, personality changes, anxiety, obsessive-compulsive behavior, or psychosis
  • Eye: KF (Kayser Fleischer) ring in Descement membrane layer of cornea (Statement 5)
  • Renal: Fanconi syndrome and renal failure

Diagnosis:

  • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin levels (<20 mg/dL)
  • Serum-free copper level >1.6 µmol/L
  • Urinary copper excretion (normally <40 µg/day) is increased to >100 µg/day
  • Liver biopsy (Gold standard): Hepatic copper content >250 µg/g dry weight of liver

Treatment:

  • Dietary intake of copper (Avoid liver, shellfish, nuts, and chocolate) should be restricted to <1 mg/day
  • Symptomatic patients: Copper-chelating agents
    • D-penicillamine (Statement 3 ruled out)
    • Triethylenetetramine dihydrochloride
  • Zinc impairs the gastrointestinal absorption of copper

questions.text: What is the formula utilized to calculate the power of the lens during cataract surgery for a patient who has previously undergone LASIK for myopia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Haigis L

Haigis formula is particularly well-regarded for post-LASIK eyes.

  • It uses two variables: axial length & anterior chamber depth, making it more adaptable to eyes that have undergone refractive surgery.
  • This adaptability generally provides more accurate IOL power calculations in post-LASIK cases.

Biometry: Method of calculating IOL power by 2 methods - Keratometry and Axial length

  • Equipments used: A scan ultrasound for axial length

Formulas used:

SRK (Option A and B)

Hoffer Q (Option C)

Holladay I

  • P= A-2.5L-0.9K
    (L= axial length)
    (K= constant)
  • Normal axial length (24 mm)
  • Short axial length (<22mm)
  • Long axial length ( >24.5 mm)

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with progressive painless loss of vision presents to the ophthalmology OPD. The fundus image of the patient is given below. What could be the probable finding and the cause of it?

choices.text: Soft exudate, central retinal vein occlusion

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Hard exudate, diabetes mellitus

  • Hard exudates are bright yellow, well-defined deposits caused by leakage of fluid rich in lipids and proteins from damaged retinal capillaries. They often form around microaneurysms and, in the macular region, can create a star-shaped pattern (macular fan/ star), which is seen most commonly in diabetic retinopathy (although it can also be seen in Hypertensive retinopathy).

Hard and Soft Exudates:

Feature

Soft Exudates (Cotton-Wool Spots)

Hard Exudates

Appearance
  • Cloud-like, small, ill-defined, whitish patches
  • Bright yellow, well-defined lipid deposits

Formation Mechanism
  • Caused by ischemia and axonal swelling; blockage of axoplasmic flow
  • Formed by leakage of fluid rich in proteins and lipids

Location
  • Superficial retinal layers, often seen around the optic nerve
  • Seen around leaking microaneurysms, especially in the macula

Common Shape
  • Indistinct and variable; may change shape quickly
  • Radial, star-shaped figure in the macula (macular fan/star)

Main Causes
  • Hypertensive retinopathy (Most common cause)
  • Diabetic retinopathy
  • Toxemia of pregnancy
  • Lupus erythematosus (LE)
  • Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN)
  • Retinopathy associated with AIDS
  • Diabetic retinopathy (Most common cause) (Option B)
  • Hypertensive retinopathy
  • Coats' disease
  • Circinate retinopathy

Image

questions.text:
Identify the surgical step shown in the image given below:

[
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Capsulorrhexis

Explanation:

  • The surgical procedure where tryphan blue dye is being injected in the image is Continuous curvilinear Capsulorrhexis. It refers to the creation of a circular tear in the anterior capsule of the lens.

 

Surgical Steps of Conventional ECCE:

  • Eye Stabilization: Superior rectus suture for downward gaze(known as bridle suture)
  • Conjunctival Flap Creation: A fornix-based flap will be used to expose the limbus.
  • Limbal Incision: Partial-thickness groove across the limbus.
  • Anterior Chamber Access: Entry with a razor blade knife or keratome.
  • Viscoelastic Injection: Maintains chamber depth and protects the cornea.
  • Anterior Capsulotomy/ Capsulorrhexis: Methods include can-opener, linear capsulotomy, envelope, or CCC. Tryphan blue dye is usually injected. (Option B)
  • Capsule Removal: Using forceps remove the cut capsule.
  • Corneoscleral Section Completion: Extending the incision.
  • Hydrodissection: Separates the lens from the capsule. (Option A)
  • Nucleus Removal: Methods include pressure/counter pressure or irrigating wire vectis.
  • Lens Cortex Aspiration: Using a two-way cannula. (I/A) (Option D)
  • IOL Implantation: Posterior chamber IOL into the capsular bag. (Option C)
  • Incision Closure: With sutures.
  • Viscoelastic Removal: Followed by refilling the anterior chamber with irrigating fluid.
  • Conjunctival Flap Repositioning: Secured in place.
  • Subconjunctival Injections: Dexamethasone and gentamicin.
  • Eye Patching: Final step.

questions.text: What is Anisometropia?

choices.text: Difference in refractive error between 2 eyes
Difference in the axial length of the eyeball
Difference in the size of the eyeball

questions.solution:
• Anisometropia is when total refraction of the two eyes is unequal.
  • The difference in power of two eyes is more than 2.5 diopters.
  • Anisometropia up to 2.5D is well tolerated and that between 2.5 and 4D can be tolerated depending upon the individual sensitivity.
  • However, if it is more than 4D, it is not tolerated and is a matter of concern.

 

Difference in visual acuity (Option A) could be caused by conditions like myopia, hypermetropia, astigmatism, and presbyopia.

Difference in axial length (Option C) of the eyeball is seen in axial myopia.

Difference in size of eyeball (Option D) is seen in conditions like Microphthalmia and Buphthalmos.

questions.text: What substance is responsible for the development of a diabetic cataract in a 68-year-old female patient, which has been present for 3 months?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Sorbitol

  • In diabetic patients, sorbitol accumulation in the lens plays a critical role in the development of diabetic cataracts. This process is primarily mediated by the polyol pathway, where glucose is converted to sorbitol via the enzyme aldose reductase. Sorbitol accumulates in the lens because it is poorly permeable across the lens membrane, leading to osmotic stress and cellular damage, which promotes cataract formation.

Glucose Metabolism in the Lens:

The lens uses glucose through several metabolic pathways:

  1. Glycolytic pathway: This is the primary pathway where about 80% of glucose is metabolized anaerobically.

  2. Pentose Phosphate pathway (HMP shunt): Responsible for metabolizing 15% of glucose.

  3. Kreb's citric acid cycle: A small proportion of glucose is metabolized through this oxidative pathway.

  4. Sorbitol pathway: In healthy individuals, this pathway is minimally active. However, in diabetic and galactosemic patients, excess glucose is converted into sorbitol by aldose reductase. The accumulation of sorbitol leads to osmotic imbalance, which causes lens fiber swelling and opacity, resulting in cataracts.

Glucose (Option A): Although glucose is involved in cataract formation, it is not directly responsible for the development of diabetic cataracts. In the lens, glucose is metabolized via several pathways, but it is the conversion of glucose to sorbitol (via the polyol pathway) that leads to osmotic stress and cataract formation in diabetes.

Fructose (Option B): Fructose does not significantly contribute to diabetic cataracts. While fructose is metabolized in the body, it is not the primary substance implicated in lens opacity in diabetic patients. The key factor in diabetic cataracts is sorbitol accumulation.

Lactose + Glucose (Option C): Lactose is not involved in the formation of diabetic cataracts. Although glucose plays a role in cataract formation, lactose is more relevant in galactosemic cataracts and not in diabetes-induced cataracts.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic woman presents with painless loss of vision. The ocular findings are shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis and management for this patient?

choices.text: Immature senile cataract and phacoemulsification with IOL

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Immature senile cataract and phacoemulsification with IOL

Explanation:

  • The patient is a 65-year-old diabetic woman with painless loss of vision, which points towards cataracts, a common cause of visual impairment, especially in older individuals and those with diabetes.
  • Immature senile cataract refers to the early stages of cataract formation, where the lens becomes cloudy but is not yet completely opaque. This typically leads to gradual loss of vision without pain.
  • The standard treatment for cataracts, especially in cases with significant visual impairment, is phacoemulsification, a surgical procedure that uses ultrasound to break up the lens, followed by removal and placement of an intraocular lens (IOL) to restore clear vision.

Type of Cataract

Characteristics

Visual Impact

Cuneiform Senile Cortical Cataract
  • Wedge-shaped opacities with clear areas in between.
  • Extends from periphery to center.
  • First appears in the lower nasal quadrant. Present in both anterior and posterior cortex.
  • The radial spoke-like pattern of opacities is seen.
  • Visual disturbances are noted at a comparatively late stage (since it starts at the periphery).
  • Vision improves in bright light with contracted pupils.

Cupuliform Senile Cortical Cataract

  • Saucer-shaped opacities are typically in the central part of the posterior cortex (posterior subcapsular cataract).
  • Extends from center to periphery.
  • Causes an early loss of visual acuity.- Due to the involvement of the nodal point
  • Glares seen in PSC
  • Better vision in dim light with dilated pupils.

Stages of Cortical cataract:

Stage

Description

Characteristics

1. Stage of Lamellar Separation

Earliest stage of senile cataract
  • Formation of vacuoles and water clefts within the cortex
  • Reversible change
  • Can only be demonstrated by slit lamp examination

2. Stage of Incipient Cataract

Detectable opacities with clear areas present between. Causes visual disturbances.

Cuneiform type:

  • Wedge-shaped opacities, extending from the equator appear as radial spoke-like opacities.

Cupuliform type:

  • Saucer-shaped opacity in the central posterior cortex.

3. Immature Senile Cataract

Progression of opacification
  • Iris shadow visible (clear cortex visible) -Iris Shadow present here due to opacities + clear areas
  • Can progress to Intumescent Cataract leading to the shallow anterior chamber.

4. Mature Senile Cataract (aka intumescent cataract)

Complete opacification of cortex
  • The lens appears pearly white
  • Referred to as a "ripe cataract"
  • No iris shadow as the whole lens is opacified with a chalky white color

5. Hypermature Senile Cataract (HMSC)

Advanced stage of cataract beyond maturity

Morgagnian Hypermature Cataract:

  • Cortex liquefies
  • Nucleus sinks to the bottom
  • Bag of milky fluid appearance

Sclerotic Hypermature Cataract:

  • The cortex disintegrates, lens and capsule shrink.
  • Deep anterior chamber
  • Iridodonesis may be present.

Incorrect Options:

Zonular cataract and lensectomy (Option A): Zonular cataract is a specific type of cataract involving changes to the lens fibers and zonules (the ligaments that hold the lens in place). While lensectomy (removal of the lens) can be performed, it is typically not the preferred term for routine cataract surgery, and this condition is not as commonly associated with the age and symptoms described here.

Rosette cataract and sugar control (Option B): A rosette cataract is a rare type of cataract that forms as a star-shaped pattern, usually associated with trauma or certain diseases, but it is not typically seen in diabetic patients or with the presentation described here. Sugar control is important for diabetes management, but it doesn't directly address the cataract-related vision loss.

Sunflower cataract and lesion extraction (Option C): A sunflower cataract is typically associated with Wilson's disease, a condition characterized by copper accumulation in tissues, leading to a distinctive appearance of the cataract. The patient does not have signs of Wilson's disease, and lesion extraction would not be appropriate for a cataract.

questions.text: What dye is used in staining for the anterior capsule of lens?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Trypan Blue

  • Trypan blue is a dye that can be used to stain the anterior capsule of the lens during certain ophthalmic surgeries, such as cataract surgery. It helps to increase the visibility of the anterior capsule of the lens, making the surgical procedure easier and safer.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Brilliant Blue: This dye is sometimes used in eye surgery, specifically for staining the internal limiting membrane (ILM) during vitrectomy procedures.

Option C - Fluorescent green (Fluorescein): This dye is used in diagnostic procedures to highlight damage to the cornea.

Option D - Lissamine Green: This dye is used in eye exams to detect damage to the eye's surface, particularly the cornea and conjunctiva.

questions.text: In which type of cataract surgery is suturing with 10-0 nylon commonly performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE)

  • In extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE), the surgeon makes a larger incision on the eye's surface, typically around 10-12 mm in size. This incision allows the surgeon to remove the cataractous lens while leaving the posterior lens capsule intact. After removing the lens, the incision is usually closed with sutures, often using 10-0 nylon. ECCE requires suturing because the incision size is relatively large, and proper wound closure is necessary to ensure the eye heals correctly and maintains its structural integrity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Phacoemulsification: Phacoemulsification is a modern and minimally invasive cataract surgery technique. In this procedure, a small incision is made through which an ultrasonic probe (phacoemulsifier) is inserted to break up the cataract into tiny fragments that are then suctioned out. Suturing with 10-0 nylon is not commonly performed in phacoemulsification surgery because the incision size is typically very small and may not require sutures to close.

Option C - Intracapsular cataract extraction (ICCE): Intracapsular cataract extraction involves removing the entire lens, including the lens capsule, in one piece. This method is now less commonly used due to advances in surgical techniques. Suturing with 10-0 nylon is not commonly performed in ICCE surgery because the procedure involves removing the entire lens and capsule, making the need for suturing less relevant.

Option D - Manual small incision cataract surgery (MSICS): Manual small incision cataract surgery is a technique similar to ECCE but uses a smaller incision (around 6-7 mm) compared to traditional ECCE. While suturing may still be performed in MSICS, the use of 10-0 nylon is more commonly associated with traditional ECCE due to the larger incision size.

questions.text: Which lens is utilized in direct gonioscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Koeppe

Explanation:

  • In direct gonioscopy, the Koeppe lens is commonly used. It is designed with a domed or slanted shape that allows light rays to pass through the contact lens/air interface at a steep angle, enabling direct visualization of the anterior chamber angle.

Direct Gonioscopy:

  • Direct gonioscopy uses a lens with a domed or slanted configuration to allow light from the eye’s angle to pass through the lens to the observer without reflection. It does not require a slit lamp and is typically performed with the patient in a supine position, often under general anesthesia for procedures like infantile glaucoma evaluation and surgery.
  • Lenses Used: Includes Koeppe, Barkan, Swan-Jacob lenses.
  • Technique:
    • Performed with the patient lying down, often using a hand-held microscope or magnifying loupes.
    • Not compatible with desktop slit lamps, limiting clarity and magnification compared to indirect gonioscopy.
  • Indications: Commonly used for evaluating and treating infantile glaucoma.

 

Goldmann lens: Typically used for indirect gonioscopy, which involves using a slit lamp for better magnification and clarity.

Zeiss lens: Also used for indirect gonioscopy with a slit lamp, offering high magnification.

Sussman lens: A type of indirect gonioscopy lens, offering wide-angle visualization but not used in direct gonioscopy.

questions.text: Which is the type of cataract seen following a blunt trauma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rosette cataract

Explanation:

Traumatic cataract: blunt trauma: Rosette cataract (Option A)

  • It is a cortical cataract that starts from the posterior cortex.

Toxic cataract:

  • Steroids - Prolonged use in high doses may cause posterior subcapsular cataracts. Children are more susceptible
  • Other causes of posterior subcapsular cataract: Galactosemia, Myotonic dystrophy, BLUNT trauma, complicated cataract, chloroquine, busulfan, NF2,
  • Glaucoma by TOPICAL steroids and cataract by SYSTEMIC STEROIDS (mnemonic: GTCS)
  • Miotics - Especially long-acting cholinesterase inhibitors such as echothiophate, demecarium bromide, and diisopropyl fluorophosphate (DFP) may cause anterior subcapsular-granular cataracts
  • Other causes of anterior subcapsular cataract - Amiodarone, chlorpromazine, busulfan, gold, and allopurinol
  • AACG ( Mnemonic): Atopic dermatitis- shield cataract, Amiodarone, Chlorpromazine, Gold deposit, AACG(acute angle closure glaucoma)

Radiation cataract: Infrared (heat) cataract-

  • Infrared aka glassblower cataract
  • Lens capsule exfoliation with discoid posterior opacities
  • X-ray, gamma rays, neutron exposure: Inadequately protected technicians, patients treated for malignant tumors, and workers of atomic energy plants are at risk.

Electric Shock cataract/ Lightening cataract: It leads to Stellate ASC

Incorrect Options:

Christmas tree cataract (Option B) is associated with Myotonic Dystrophy.

Snowflake cataract (Option C) Diabetes mellitus is associated with Snowflake cataract

Sunflower cataract (Option D) is associated with Wilson’s disease

questions.text: Oil drop cataract is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Galactosemia

Explanation:

Galactosemia cataracts cause oil drop cataract.

Galactosemia

Inborn error of galactose metabolism

Enzyme deficiency

  • Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GPUT)
  • Galactokinase (GK)

Type of cataract

  • Bilateral
  • “Oil droplet” (Option A)
  • Central lens

Features

  • May be reversed
  • May be prevented if milk and milk products are eliminated at an early stage

Wilson's disease (Option B) primarily affects the liver and brain, and produces sunflower cataracts and Kayser-Fleischer ring in the cornea.

Gaucher's disease and Tay-Sachs (Option C and D) disease are lysosomal storage disorders and are not associated with oil drop cataracts.

questions.text: After cataract surgery, a patient develops endophthalmitis with vision limited to hand movements. What is the treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Intravitreal antibiotic injections

Explanation: Acute endophthalmitis:

Definition
  • Inflammation of inner structures of the eye (uveal tissue and retina) with exudates in the vitreous, anterior, and posterior chambers. It spares sclera.
  • Acute bacterial endophthalmitis happens 1-7 days post intraocular surgery

M/C causative organism
  • Staphylococcus epidermidis

Presentation

  • Severe ocular pain
  • Redness
  • Lacrimation
  • Photophobia
  • Loss of vision
  • Red and swollen lids
  • Conjunctival chemosis
  • Circumcorneal congestion
  • Cloudy cornea
  • Ring infiltration
  • Yellow necrotic wound edges
  • Hypopyon
  • Oedematous and muddy iris
  • Yellow pupil reflex due to purulent exudation
  • Vitreous exudation which causes amaurotic cat's-eye reflex
  • Raised intraocular pressure initially

Treatment

  • Intravitreal antibiotics (Option A):
    • First choice: Vancomycin 1 mg + Ceftazidime 2.25 mg
    • Second choice: Vancomycin 1 mg + Amikacin 0.4 mg
  • Topical antibiotics (Option D)
  • Systemic antibiotics
  • Steroid Therapy
  • Supportive Therapy
  • Vitrectomy - if no improvement in 48-72 hours (Option B) or if severe infection with vision reduced to hand movements close to the face
  • If blind - no perception of light - Evisceration.

Redo surgery (Option C) is not the right surgical approach for endophthalmitis.

questions.text: Which of the following cataracts is seen in blunt trauma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rosette cataract

Explanation: Rosette-shaped cataract: it is a cortical cataract that starts from the posterior cortex is seen in blunt trauma.

Traumatic cataract:

  • A traumatic cataract is an acquired cataract resulting from ocular trauma, such as penetrating or blunt injuries.
  • It forms due to degeneration in previously normal lens fibers.
  • Morphological Forms
    • Subepithelial Opacities: Most common presentation.
    • Rosette Cataracts
      • Early Rosette: Feathery opacities along posterior cortex suture lines; typical of concussion cataracts. (Option C)
      • Late Rosette: Develops 1-2 years post-injury, with shorter, compact sutural extensions.
      • Diffuse Concussion Cataract: Common presentation of total cataract following blunt trauma, which may accelerate senile cataract development.
  • Subepithelial Opacities (Option A) are common but do not typically present with feathery opacities along suture lines.
  • Diffuse Concussion Cataract (Option B) involves widespread lens opacity, not localized feathery patterns..

Toxic cataract (Option B) causes posterior subcapsular cataract. It can be caused by steroids, phenothiazines, mong acting miotics, amiodarone, busulfan, gold, chloroquine

Metabolic cataract (Option C):

  • Due to Diabetes mellitus
  • It can occur due to 2 enzyme deficiencies
    • Galactokinase - causes lamellar cataract
    • GPUT - causes oil drop cataract

Nuclear cataract (Option D):

  • It is due to nuclear sclerosis
  • Sclerosis can be caused due to denaturation of the protein resulting in an increase in insoluble protein and a decrease in soluble protein, and deposition of pigments such as melanin and urochrome.

questions.text: A 2-month-old child is brought to the ophthalmology OPD with the following presentation. What is the ideal management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Operate immediately:

  • In this situation, the image reveals bilateral congenital cataracts, meaning both eyes are affected. If not treated promptly, this condition can result in irreversible vision loss due to amblyopia. For bilateral cataracts, surgery is typically performed after the child reaches one month of age, so immediate surgery is necessary in this case.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text: A patient presents with decreased vision three years after surgery and exhibits this condition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Posterior capsular opacification (PCO):

  • Posterior Capsular Opacification can occur after cataract surgery when residual lens epithelial cells migrate and proliferate on the posterior capsule. Elschnig Pearls are clusters of proliferating lens epithelial cells that form a circular, pearl-like opacity on the posterior capsule, contributing to the visual disturbances( as seen in the given image).

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C do not exhibit Elschnig pearls.

questions.text: A patient with a long-standing history of diabetes presents with cataracts. Which of the following metabolic products is primarily responsible for cataract formation in this condition?
questions.solution:
• In individuals with diabetes, high blood glucose levels can lead to increased activity of the enzyme aldose reductase. This enzyme converts glucose to sorbitol.
  • Sorbitol is poorly metabolized and can accumulate within the lens of the eye.
  • The accumulation of sorbitol leads to osmotic changes, drawing water into the lens and causing it to swell. This swelling and disruption of lens fibers leads to cataract formation.

 

Pathophysiology of Diabetic Cataract Formation:

  1. Glucose enters the lens (insulin-independent uptake).
  2. Aldose reductase converts glucose → sorbitol .
  3. Sorbitol accumulates (since its conversion to fructose by sorbitol dehydrogenase is slow in the lens).
  4. Sorbitol is osmotically active, causing lens swelling, oxidative stress, and crystallin protein aggregation → cataract formation.


 

Mannitol (Option A): Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic and is not involved in cataract formation.

 

Galactitol (Option B): Galactitol (dulcitol) accumulates in the lens in galactosemia, leading to early-onset cataracts, but not in diabetic cataracts.

 

Fructose (Option D): While sorbitol is eventually converted to fructose by sorbitol dehydrogenase, the rate is slow in the lens, making sorbitol the primary culprit in diabetic cataracts.

questions.text: A patient, 36 hours after cataract surgery, presents with complaints of pain and visual disturbance. His eye is as shown below. What is the management of this condition?

choices.text: Bandage and padding of the eye

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Intravitreal antibiotics:

  • Given image of eye shows inflammation, congestion, corneal edema and hypopyon after 36 hours of undergoing cataract surgery is suggestive of acute onset endophthalmitis
  • Treatment of acute onset endophthalmitis will depend upon whether the patient is able to perceive the hand movement or doesn't have hand movement.
    • In the case of only perception of light and no hand movement, Pars Plana Vitrectomy (PPV) helps to quickly reduce the incidence of vision loss by 50%.
    • When there is hand movement and above, the treatment of choice would be intravitreal antibiotic injections (ceftazidime (gram -ve) and vancomycin (gram +ve)).
    • Systemic antibiotics, mainly Quinolones, are preferred. Topical steroids and cycloplegics are used in the case of uveitis.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text: Rosette cataract is seen after?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Blunt trauma to eye:

  • Rosette-shaped cataract a cortical cataract that starts from the posterior cortex, also known as traumatic cataract, is a type of cataract that occurs as a result of blunt trauma to the eye. The impact from the trauma can cause disruption and damage to the lens, leading to the formation of a characteristic rosette-like pattern in the lens fibers.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Copper foreign body in eye:  It can lead to Sunflower cataract.

Option C - Penetrating injury to the eye: A penetrating injury can result in sympathetic ophthalmitis.

Option D - Infection: Infections of the eye, such as endophthalmitis, can lead to severe inflammation and damage to various eye structures, including the lens.

questions.text: Ectopia lentis is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A -Homocystinuria:

  • Ectopia lentis refers to the abnormal displacement or dislocation of the lens of the eye. It can occur as a result of various underlying conditions. Among the given options condition associated with ectopia lentis is homocystinuria.
  • Other diseases associated with ectopia lentis are:
    • Marfan syndrome.
    • Weill Marchesani syndrome.
    • Ehler’s Danlos syndrome.
    • Hyperlysinemia.
    • Sulphite oxidase deficiency.
    • Stickler syndrome.
       

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Refsum's disease: Refsum's disease, also known as heredopathia atactica polyneuritiformis, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of phytanic acid in the body. It primarily affects the nervous system and other organs but is not associated with ectopia lentis.

Option C - Wilson's disease: Wilson's disease is an inherited disorder that leads to abnormal copper metabolism in the body, resulting in copper accumulation in various organs, particularly the liver and brain. It manifest as Kayser-Fleischer ring in the cornea.

Option D - Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is a systemic inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs, including the eyes. Ocular manifestations inlude band-shaped keratopathy, and uveitis.

questions.text: What could be the likely diagnosis for a 55-year-old male patient who visited the OPD with complaints of experiencing glare while driving at night, despite having cataract surgery a year ago? The patient's best corrected visual acuity is 6/12 in the right eye and 6/9 in the left eye, with no improvement observed when using a pinhole.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Posterior capsular opacification:

  • Based on the patient's history of cataract surgery and the symptoms of glare during night drives, posterior capsular opacification is the most likely diagnosis.
  • During cataract surgery, the posterior capsule of the lens is left intact to support the intraocular lens (IOL) implant. It is caused by the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that have remained within the capsular bag fol-lowing cataract extraction. . This condition is known as posterior capsular opacification (PCO) or secondary cataract or after cataract.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cystoid macular edema: Cystoid macular edema (CME) is a condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the macula, which is the central part of the retina responsible for sharp central vision. It is characterized by blurring, especially for near tasks, and sometimes distortion.

Option B - Pseudophakic bullous keratopathy: Pseudophakic bullous keratopathy is a condition that can occur after cataract surgery, characterized by corneal edema and swelling.

Option C - ARMD (Age-Related Macular Degeneration): Age-related macular degeneration is a progressive degenerative disease affecting the macula, which leads to central vision loss. It commonly presents in individuals over the age of 50 and can cause symptoms such as blurred or distorted central vision.
